ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about the history of revolutions in cities around the world.

This course gives you a ton of material not only about famous case study revolutions in history (like the American Revolution, the Paris Commune, Tiananmen Square, May 68, Arab Spring, Occupy etc.), but you also examine common elements across them and look at broader theory around how revolutions and urban space protest happens.
the histories of important social and political movements of the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries and how the spatial and architectural features of the cities in which they occurred informed them

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths were that it covered a lot of different events throughout history.  I would like to have seen a little bit more variety with teaching material but overall it was a good class that taught me a lot.
I wish there would have been more student discussion, especially from the readings.

Strengths: The course reviews so many important revolutionary moments worth knowing the background about. I loved that we didnt talk just about the reasons why a revolution occurred, but specifically looked at its relationship to space and the city where it unfolded, and also often discussed how art was used in each. Weaknesses: The only drawback I think would be that there wasnt as much seminar discussion time as I would have hoped, but Prof. Plattus has so much fascinating knowledge to share that you barely notice.

Because each seminar was a case study of a different city (sometimes a few), movement, or historical moment, it sometimes felt like a new class every week. Lack of continuity could be seen as a weakness, but also allowed us to go in depth and explore different movements based on direction of class discussion. Combination of history and theory (mostly spatial analysis and some architectural theory) was a definite strength.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a simple straightforward class in which you knew what was expected from you at the very beginning and I appreciate that.
Single two hour class once a week definitely not ideal over Zoom, but class was so interesting it didn't really matter.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to other students. This has been one of my favorite Yale courses I've taken.
It is a lot of reading and then a 2 hour lecture and discussion on the events.

I would definitely recommend this class! However I would only recommend it to someone who is really interested in the material, as the weekly reading load can be pretty heavy and the final research paper is long.
